Sentence: Good afternoon.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Today the Federal Open Market Committee decided to raise the target range for the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point, bringing it to 1¼ to 1½ percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Our decision reflects our assessment that a gradual removal of monetary policy accommodation will sustain a strong labor market while fostering a return of inflation to 2 percent, consistent with the maximum employment and price stability objectives assigned to us by law.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Before saying more about our decision, I’ll review recent economic developments and the outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Following a slowdown in the first quarter, economic growth stepped up to a solid 3¼ percent pace in the second and third quarters of the year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Household spending has been expanding at a moderate rate, business investment has picked up, and favorable economic conditions abroad have supported exports.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Overall, we continue to expect that the economy will expand at a moderate pace.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: While changes in tax policy will likely provide some lift to economic activity in coming years, the magnitude and timing of the macroeconomic effects of any tax package remain uncertain.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Smoothing through hurricane-related fluctuations, job gains averaged 170,000 per month over the three months ending in November, well above estimates of the pace necessary to absorb new entrants to the labor force.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The unemployment rate has declined further in recent months and, at 4.1 percent in November, was modestly below the median of FOMC participants’ estimates of its longer-run normal level.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Broader measures of labor market utilization have also continued to strengthen.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Participation in the labor force has changed little, on net, over the past four years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Given the underlying downward trend in participation stemming largely from the aging of the U.S. population, a relatively steady participation rate is a further sign of improved conditions in the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We expect that the job market will remain strong in the years ahead.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: You may have noticed that we altered the statement language about the labor market outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: This change highlights that the Committee expects the labor market to remain strong, with sustained job creation, ample opportunities for workers, and rising wages.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We anticipate some further strengthening in labor market conditions in the months ahead; however, we expect the pace of job gains to moderate over time as we gradually reduce the degree of monetary policy accommodation.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Allowing the labor market to overheat would raise the risk that monetary policy would need to tighten abruptly at a later stage, jeopardizing the economic expansion.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Even with a firming of economic growth and a stronger labor market, inflation has continued to run below the FOMC’s 2 percent longer-run objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The 12-month change in the price index for personal consumption expenditures was 1.6 percent in October, up a bit from the summer but still below rates seen earlier in the year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Core inflation—which excludes the volatile food and energy categories—has followed a similar pattern and was 1.4 percent in October.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We continue to believe that this year’s surprising softness in inflation primarily reflects transitory developments that are largely unrelated to broader economic conditions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As a result, we still expect inflation will move up and stabilize around 2 percent over the next couple of years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Nonetheless, as I’ve noted previously, our understanding of the forces driving inflation is imperfect.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As emphasized in our statement, we will carefully monitor actual and expected inflation developments relative to our symmetric inflation goal.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, as I’ve noted before, we are prepared to adjust monetary policy as needed to achieve our inflation and employment objectives over the medium term.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Let me turn to the economic projections that Committee participants submitted for this meeting.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As always, participants conditioned their projections on their own individual views of appropriate monetary policy, which, in turn, depend on each participant’s assessment of the many factors that shape the outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The median projection for growth of inflation-adjusted gross domestic product, or real GDP, is 2½ percent this year and next and moderates to 2 percent by 2020, a bit above its estimated longer-run rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The median projection for the unemployment rate stands at 4.1 percent in the fourth quarter of this year and runs close to 4 percent over the next three years, modestly below the median estimate of its longer-run normal rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Finally, the median inflation projection is 1.7 percent this year, 1.9 percent next year, and 2 percent in 2019 and 2020.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Compared with the projections made in September, real GDP growth is a little stronger, the unemployment rate is a bit lower, and inflation is essentially unchanged.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Participants generally identified changes in tax policy as a factor supporting this modestly stronger outlook, although many noted that much uncertainty remains about the macroeconomic effects of the specific measures that ultimately may be implemented.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Returning to monetary policy, for the past two years the FOMC has been gradually increasing its target range for the federal funds rate as the economy has continued to make progress toward our goals of maximum employment and price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Our decision today continues this process.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We still expect that the ongoing strength of the economy will warrant gradual increases in the federal funds rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: That expectation is based on our view that this rate remains somewhat below its neutral level—that is, the level that is neither expansionary nor contractionary and keeps the economy operating on an even keel.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Because the neutral rate currently appears to be quite low by historical standards, the federal funds rate would not have to rise much further to get to a neutral policy stance.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But because we also expect the neutral level of the federal funds rate to rise somewhat over time, additional gradual rate hikes are likely to be appropriate over the next few years to sustain a strong labor market and stabilize inflation around our 2 percent longer-run objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Even so, the Committee continues to anticipate that the longer-run neutral level of the federal funds rate is likely to remain below levels that prevailed in previous decades.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: This view is consistent with participants’ projections of appropriate monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The median projection for the federal funds rate is 2.1 percent at the end of next year, 2.7 percent at the end of 2019, and 3.1 percent in 2020.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Compared with the projections made in September, the median path for the federal funds rate is unchanged through 2019 and a touch higher in 2020.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I should note that the economic outlook is highly uncertain, and participants will adjust their assessments of the appropriate path for the federal funds rate as their economic outlooks and views of the risks to the outlook change.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Policy is not on a preset course.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Additionally, the Committee’s balance sheet normalization program, initiated in October, is proceeding.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As we’ve noted previously, changing the target range for the federal funds rate is our primary means of adjusting the stance of monetary policy, and we do not foresee a need to alter our balance sheet normalization program.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Hence, our statement no longer mentions this program.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Of course, we would be prepared to resume reinvestments if a material deterioration in the economic outlook were to warrant a sizable reduction in the federal funds rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Finally, I’d like to note that, although I have one more FOMC meeting to attend in the New Year, this will be my last scheduled news conference.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Over the next month and a half, I will do my utmost to ensure a smooth transition to my designated successor, Jay Powell.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I am confident that he is as deeply committed as I have been to the Federal Reserve’s vital public mission.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Thank you for being such an attentive audience these past four years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, as always, I’ll be happy to take your questions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’m Marty Crutsinger, Associated Press.
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: Madam Chair, could you give us any insight into the discussion and how it dealt with the major tax changes that Congress is considering now?
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: There have been thoughts that with these changes happening at a time when the economy is already—with unemployment so low—that the Fed may be forced to increase its pace on rate hikes.
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: Did any of that discussion come up in your meeting?
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: So, yes, we did discuss tax policy, and let me say that most of my colleagues factored in the prospect of fiscal stimulus along the lines of what’s being contemplated by Congress into their projections.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Now, I should emphasize that some have been incorporating those expectations into their projections throughout the year, so changes to the projections that you see since September should not be viewed as an impact—an estimate of the impact of the tax package.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, in particular, broader expectations of changes to fiscal policy have been reflected in financial market conditions, I think, over the past year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: For example, we have seen a significant increase in the stock market, and at least some portion of that, I would judge, likely partly reflected expected tax changes, and that effect—along with other financial market effects, which affects, for example, projected consumer spending and would have affected wealth—that’s been part of participants’ forecasts now for some time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I think my colleagues and I are in line with the general expectation among most economists that the type of tax changes that are likely to be enacted would tend to provide some modest lift to GDP growth in the coming years, and you see that—in part, that’s one of the reasons, I think, for the uptick you see in estimated growth and decline in the unemployment rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The views of participants, I believe, have been informed by a wide range of analysis, including that of the Joint Committee on Taxation and other outside evaluators, and my sense is that their estimates are essentially in the same ballpark, although they recognize, as I emphasized, that there is considerable uncertainty about the impacts, and that will have to be monitored over time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: More specifically, they tend to see the package as boosting both consumer spending and capital spending, to some extent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Now, to the extent that the changes do have positive impact on the growth of potential GDP and longer-run growth, let me just say that this is something that, should it occur, would be very welcome to participants, as long as it’s consistent with the attainment of our employment and inflation objectives.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I guess I would also urge you to remember that when you look at the projections, that there are many factors that affect those projections, and changes in tax policy—that’s only one of a number of factors, including incoming data that has, to some extent, altered the outlook for growth and inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: All of that factors into the projections you see.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But I think, bottom line, when you look at assessments of the funds rate path, participants continue to see gradual increases in the target range for the federal funds rate as being appropriate to sustain a strong labor market and bring inflation back to 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, look—importantly, there is a lot of uncertainty about what the likely effects will be, and my colleagues and I will be committed, as always, to evaluating incoming data and altering the outlook as appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Harriet Torry with Dow Jones Newswires.
Speaker: HARRIET TORRY.

Sentence: You and others at the Fed have said that soft inflation should be transitory.
Speaker: HARRIET TORRY.

Sentence: Are you confident that that will still be the case, particularly regarding wage gains?
Speaker: HARRIET TORRY.

Sentence: They’ve been pretty moderate in recent months, yet the economy is growing and confidence is high.
Speaker: HARRIET TORRY.

Sentence: Is there something going on in the economy that’s making it difficult for businesses to raise wages?
Speaker: HARRIET TORRY.

Sentence: So it is true that incoming wage data suggests only modest upward pressure on wages.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: That leaves me—that’s one factor, along with the fact that inflation remains low—with feeling that even though we have a 4.1 percent unemployment rate, that the labor market is not overheated at this point.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Remember, the modest pace of wage gains also probably reflects slow productivity growth.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But when you ask me about the outlook for inflation, you know, I’ve talked in detail about this in the past and recognize that there is uncertainty about what’s holding inflation down.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But my colleagues and I continue to believe that the factors that are responsible this year for holding inflation down are likely to prove transitory.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: That said, we all agree that our inflation objective is extremely important.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We recognize that there’s been a prolonged shortfall.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: This is a symmetric 2 percent inflation objective, and we continue to indicate that we’ll be monitoring inflation developments closely.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And so this is on the horizon and recognized to be one of the risks facing policy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Thank you.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: Nick Timiraos, the Wall Street Journal.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: Chair Yellen, I wanted to follow up on the question about tax changes.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: When you addressed it earlier today, and when you spoke to Congress last month, you often describe that you would welcome higher growth in the context of the employment and inflation mandate.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: And I guess I wonder how you judge the major provisions of the House and Senate tax plans:  the corporate rate cut, immediate expensing of big-ticket purchases, new rates for pass-throughs, temporary rate cuts for individuals.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: Do you see those, on balance, boosting the productive capacity of the U.S. economy as opposed to simply increasing aggregate demand?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: And, related to that, how would you view the benefit of such tax changes now, when the economy is nearing full employment, versus at earlier periods when there was greater resource slack?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: So I think my colleagues and I mainly see the likely tax package as boosting aggregate demand, but also having some potential to boost aggregate supply.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So changes on the corporate tax side—the reduction in the corporate tax rate, expensing—will lower the cost of capital.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And while there are a range of estimates and uncertainty about how much stimulus that will provide to investment, in general I would see some stimulus to investment.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: In terms of aggregate supply effects, a stronger pace of investment could boost capital formation and thereby raise productivity growth and potential GDP or output to some extent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Exactly how large those effects might be remain uncertain, but that is a channel.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I suppose it’s also possible—I’m uncertain how significant this would be—that lower marginal effective tax rates for those groups that will see them could boost labor supply.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, again, there are a range of estimates in the literatures.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I indicated I think participants have reviewed a number of pieces of analysis, including the Joint Committee on Taxation estimates, and the many outside analysts who have weighed in on this and been influenced by that kind of analysis—but there is a good deal of uncertainty about what the impacts would be.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, to the extent that there are larger impacts than those analyses assume on aggregate supply or potential GDP, in the context of an economy that has had disturbingly low productivity growth, that would be welcome and could support faster GDP growth, at least for some period, without—you know, without creating a need to tighten monetary policy to offset that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So there are potentially both demand and supply effects here.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So, importantly, you really don’t, at the end of the day, see very much change in the federal funds rate path.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Participants do recognize that the unemployment rate is lower than their estimates of its long-run sustainable rate, so I think we are in the vicinity of full employment.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Heather Long from the Washington Post.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentence: You have mentioned that the Committee thinks there will be wage increases next year.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentence: I’m wondering if you could clarify if that is coming in part or mostly from the changes to the tax plan.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentence: Is that what the expectation is, would drive the wage increases?
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentence: And I was also wondering, I’ve heard from so many female economists in academia and at the Fed about what an inspiration you’ve been to them and how melancholy they will be to see you go.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentence: I was wondering if you just had any final words to young females and minorities who may be looking to enter economics or a banking profession and rise to your level.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentence: I’m sorry, remind me of the first part of your question.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: [Laughter] HEATHER LONG.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Wages.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Wages, yes.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Is the tax policy driving wage increase expectations?
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentence: Well, I think, generally, in a strong labor market where many firms are having difficulty finding qualified workers, we would expect, just through normal demand and supply channels, to see some upward pressure on wage growth over time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And as the labor market is tightened, we’ve seen some very gradual drift upward in wage gains.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: They remain—it remains at a low level, but I would expect, in the context of an ongoing strong labor market, to see some upward pressure.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I believe that’s the main thing that my colleagues are factoring in.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: On your question on advice to women and minorities, in the Federal Reserve, my colleagues and I are very focused on wanting to see and do what we can to foster greater participation of women and minorities in economics.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We would love to, if we could, increase our hiring ourselves of women and minorities, and we see that both women and minorities are studying economics in disproportionately and disturbingly low numbers.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Although the women in STEM fields generally are about even with men—represent about 50 percent—in economics, women majors constitute something like 30 percent of undergraduate majors, and there is disproportionate low enrollment of minorities.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I will just say, from my own experience, I think economics is a terrific field.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’ve thoroughly enjoyed my career in economics and think there are many different paths that people can follow that lead to satisfying careers, and that there are very interesting and important questions that economics addresses.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And it is a great field, and I would like to encourage greater involvement and think that people will find that satisfying.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, just in terms of the kinds of research that’s done in the field, I think also a greater diversity, more women and minorities, may change the focus to some extent of the questions that people choose to look at and the analysis that they bring and a range of thinking that bears on research.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And all of that would be a healthy development.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Steve Liesman, CNBC.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentence: Every day, it seems, we look at the stock market, it goes up triple digits in the Dow Jones.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentence: To what extent are there concerns at the Federal Reserve about current market valuations, and do they now or should they, do you think, if we keep going on this trajectory—should that animate monetary policy?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentence: Finally, maybe as a sign of what’s been going on with valuations, this cryptocurrency called bitcoin keeps going up every day.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentence: What is the policy of the central bank of the United States of the introduction, use, and incredible rise in popularity of bitcoin?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentence: Okay.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So let me start, Steve, with the stock market generally.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I mean, of course the stock market has gone up a great deal this year, and we have in recent months characterized the general level of asset valuations as “elevated.”  What that reflects is simply the assessment that, looking at price/earnings ratios and comparable metrics for other assets other than equities, we see ratios that are at the high end of historical ranges—and so that’s worth pointing out.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But economists are not great at knowing what appropriate valuations are.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We don’t have a terrific record, and the fact that those valuations are high doesn’t mean that they are necessarily overvalued.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We are in a—I’ve mentioned this in my opening statement, and we’ve talked about this repeatedly—likely a low interest rate environment, lower than we’ve had in past decades.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And if that turns out to be the case, that’s a factor that supports higher valuations.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We’re enjoying solid economic growth with low inflation, and the risks in the global economy look more balanced than they have in many years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I think what we need to and are trying to think through is, if there were an adjustment in asset valuations or the stock market, what impact would that have on the economy, and would it provoke financial stability concerns?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I think when we look at other indicators of financial stability risks, there’s nothing flashing red there or possibly even orange.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We have a much more resilient, stronger banking system, and we’re not seeing some worrisome buildup in leverage or credit growth at successive levels.1  So, you know, this is something that the FOMC pays attention to, but if you ask me, is this a significant factor shaping monetary policy now, well, it’s on the list of risks, it’s not a major—it’s not a major factor.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And then you asked about bitcoin, and there I would simply say that bitcoin at this time plays a very small role in the payment system.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It is not a stable source of—store of value, and it                                                  doesn’t constitute legal tender.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It is a highly speculative asset, and the Fed doesn’t really play any role—any regulatory role with respect to bitcoin other than assuring that banking organizations that we do supervise are attentive, that they’re appropriately managing any interactions they have with participants in that market and appropriately monitoring anti-money-laundering Bank Secrecy Act, you know, responsibilities that they have.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Has there been a directive, or, more importantly, has there been a directive about bitcoin to the banks and their dealings with bitcoin from the Federal Reserve?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentence: I don’t believe there’s been anything specific about that, just, generally, banks have Bank Secrecy Act anti-money-laundering responsibilities, and this applies to bitcoin as it does in every other realm.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Hi, Chair Yellen, Donna Borak with CNN.
Speaker: DONNA BORAK.

Sentence: To return back to the prospective tax bill questions, in your view at all, is the Republican tax bill an ill-timed fiscal stimulus, and are you concerned at all it will wind up squandering the tools both the Congress and the Fed have when it comes time to dealing with a recession?
Speaker: DONNA BORAK.

Sentence: So, look, I will just say that it is up to the Administration and Congress to decide on appropriate fiscal policy, and our job is to maintain our focus on employment and inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We continue to think, as you can see from the projections, that a gradual path of rate increases remains appropriate even with almost all participants now factoring in their assessment of the impact of the tax—the tax policy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: You know, it is projected that the tax cut package will lead to additions to the national debt and boost, by the end of the horizon, the debt-to-GDP ratio.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I will say—and this is nothing new, this is something I’ve been saying for a long time—I am personally concerned about the U.S. debt situation.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It’s not that the debt-to-GDP ratio at the moment is extraordinarily or worrisomely high, but it’s also not very low.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And it’s projected, as the population continues to age and the baby boomers retire, that that ratio will continue to rise in an unsustainable fashion.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So the addition to the debt, taking what is already a significant problem and making it worse, is—it is of concern to me, and I think it does suggest that in some future downturn, which, well, could occur just for whatever reason, the amount of fiscal space that would exist for fiscal policy to play an active role, it will be limited—may well be limited.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Sam Fleming from the Financial Times.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: A couple of longer-term questions.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: First of all, midway through the year you talked about the issue of whether inflation targets might need to be raised.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: There’s obviously been a lot more debate in the Fed’s system since then about this.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: It may not be an imminent issue, but do you expect it to be something the Fed should be discussing over the coming years as some sort of change to the inflation target?
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: Second of all, the amount of stimulus tools that the Fed may have at its disposal when the next downturn strikes are fairly limited.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: One of the incoming governors, Marvin Goodfriend, has talked about the merits of negative interest rates.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: I just wondered whether you see that as a potential—or at least in theory, for the Fed to consider should it run out of other options.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: Thanks.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: So right now the FOMC is not discussing or considering its inflation target.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We do see inflation as likely moving up to target over the next couple of years, and I would say—you said our stimulus tools are limited.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I would want to emphasize that if there were a negative shock to the economy, we do have some scope to cut the fed funds rate, and there are other tools available, ones that we have used previously:  forward guidance and asset purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I think we’re not—I wouldn’t say that we’re out of ammunition, but certainly it’s been recognized—and I’ve emphasized myself that, in the longer run, we may be—and we’ll have to see how this works out, but we may be in low interest rate environments where it could prove useful to have additional scope to conduct monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, in that context, I think additional research—the academic economists and others are thinking hard about what more could be done, and I think these are matters that are certainly worthy of further study.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So you do believe that negative interest rates, at least in theory, are possible in the U.S. at some point if it should be necessary—at least in theory.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentence: So, I mean, on that I would say we have—that’s not something that we have studied inside the Fed to any considerable extent and haven’t seriously thought about using ourselves during this last downturn and recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We have watched what’s happened in other countries.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I think that’s worthwhile.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I would say it’s an area that academics may have interest in in the future and is worthy of some study, but it hasn’t been part of the Fed’s agenda.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Hi, Chair Yellen.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentence: Victoria Guida with Politico.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentence: I just wanted to ask you quickly, on the regulatory side, in your testimony to Congress recently you spoke positively about the Senate bank regulatory reform bill, and I was wondering if there are—beyond that bill—if there are tweaks to Dodd-Frank that you think might still be beneficial.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentence: And then, somewhat related, Governor Powell recently said that there are currently no U.S. banks that are too big to fail.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentence: And I was wondering, do you agree with that assessment?
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentence: Well, I mean, you know, I think I’m not familiar with every detail of the bill, but I think the bill does address a wide range of issues that, you know, we’ve highlighted in the past as being ones where perhaps additional flexibility to tailor our supervisory requirements would be worthwhile.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I don’t have additional things on the congressional list.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Sorry, and what—the other thing— VICTORIA GUIDA.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Too big to fail.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Oh, too big to fail.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Are there any banks that are too big to fail right now?
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentence: So, you know, we continue to work seriously on resolution and the resolution plans, the living wills, and the structure of systemic firms to ensure that it would be possible to resolve a firm—under the bankruptcy code would be the top choice of methods, or, alternatively, under the Orderly Liquidation Authority.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I think it’s fair to say that, over time, we have learned more ourselves and more clearly detailed our expectations for the firms that file living wills.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And the firms themselves have made considerable progress in, you know, changing what they do, whether it’s adopting financial contracts that would facilitate a resolution rather than a disorderly unwinding of contracts, making sure that they’re appropriately dealing with shared services so that key services would be able to continue, governance arrangements, legal entity structures—the firms have all made progress in adapting to our expectations of what would enable a successful resolution.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I think it’s an ongoing process, and I believe we have made substantial progress.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Binya Appelbaum, the New York Times.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: I’m struggling to reconcile the pieces of the economic outlook that you’ve described today.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: You’ve said that we are basically at full employment.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: You’ve said that you’re expecting a tax package to deliver a significant stimulus, and that it will be on the demand side.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: You expect growth to be faster.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: You expect unemployment to be lower, and yet somehow inflation is going to remain at 2 percent for the foreseeable future.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: Could you describe what has changed about your economic assessment so that everything has changed except inflation?
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: Well, you know, the projections that we’re showing you today, many factors went into that, fiscal policy being one of a number of different factors.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, you know, you’re looking at 16 participants who have made adjustments to their economic outlook for a whole variety of reasons, including, in some cases, rethinking some of the fundamentals that went into their original forecast.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So there have been modifications in different directions by different participants.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I would caution you about the dangers of looking at the median and acting like that is one individual who has made a change to their forecast.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: That’s a leap that isn’t quite justified.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But, look, generally, you see modestly faster growth over the next couple of years, which is consistent and, I said, I think for most participants, reflects partly an impact from taxes stimulating consumer and investment spending.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But it’s not a gigantic increase in growth that since—relative to September.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: You do see a lower path for unemployment, but remember that inflation has also been running low on a persistent basis, and the Committee does have a concern about inflation and wants to see it moving up.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, on balance, you see only modest changes, slight revisions to the path for the fed funds rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: You might think, well, shouldn’t I see more?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Well, okay, growth is a little stronger, the unemployment rate runs a little bit lower—that would perhaps push in the direction of slightly tighter monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But, again, counterbalancing that is that inflation has run lower than we expect, and, you know, it could take a longer period of a very strong labor market in order to achieve the inflation objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Justine Underhill, Yahoo Finance.
Speaker: JUSTINE UNDERHILL.

Sentence: So William Dudley of the New York Fed recently said that the Fed is exploring the idea of potentially having its own cryptocurrency or digital currency.
Speaker: JUSTINE UNDERHILL.

Sentence: What use do you see a cryptocurrency could have for the Fed, and do you see the potential of a cryptocurrency that might be considered legal tender?
Speaker: JUSTINE UNDERHILL.

Sentence: So I want to distinguish carefully between digital currency and cryptocurrency.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: This is—there is a discussion going on among central bankers about the potential merits of adopting—a central bank itself adopting a digital currency.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And there might even be a central banker or two around the globe that might go in that direction.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But I really want to caution that this is not something the Federal Reserve is seriously considering at this stage while we’re looking at research on this topic.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: There are, I think, to my mind, limited benefits from introducing it, a limited need for it, and some substantial concerns.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And so I would really doubt that the Federal Reserve would soon go in that direction.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But it is something that central banks are looking at to see if there could be benefits from doing it.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Chair Yellen, before I ask this question, thanks for your stewardship of the economy, the benefits of which I’ve seen in some of the harder-hit parts of my own family, so— CHAIR YELLEN.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: Thank you.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: Your tenure.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: We’ve seen six Federal Reserve presidents appointed.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: One was a woman and five are men, so I’d like to know how that comports with your commitment to gender diversity.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: And, second, I wonder if you think this process of appointing Reserve Bank presidents needs to be more transparent and accountable.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: Recently, the Richmond Fed board took 11 months, and they came up with a candidate who was another Fed board member.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: And so I’m wondering what you would say to critics who say that looks like cronyism, and if you think, you know, this could be simply a more open process.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: These are votes on national monetary policy, after all.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: So I would agree with you that these are important appointments.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Under the Federal Reserve Act, the nonbanking directors of the Reserve Banks have responsibility for conducting a search, and the Board of Governors has to sign off on the candidates.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We’ve made very clear and we monitor ongoing searches very carefully to make sure that absolutely every effort is made to create a pool that is diverse, and that there be a national search, and that every attempt should be made to create a diverse pool.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: At the end of the day, we cannot guarantee that the outcomes of these searches will result in an increase in diversity.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I mean, I’ve been very pleased to see that there’s been some success in that regard, but we have signed off on the individuals who were appointed and have held the view that these are individuals who were qualified to serve in these positions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I would hope—I would hope to see greater diversity.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It has been a challenge to achieve that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Should the process be more open somehow?
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentence: Well, I think the process has become more open, and in a number of the recent searches there has been outreach—public outreach, information on websites, acceptance of potential names and nominees, and those have gotten careful consideration.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: There has been—there have been meetings in some cases with community groups to try to enlarge the pool and get suggestions, and I think that’s appropriate, and I think it has moved in the direction you’re suggesting.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer with Marketplace.
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentence: I’m wondering if you have any advice for incoming Chair Powell?
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentence: Well, my colleague—I’ve had the pleasure of working with him now for many years, and he is somebody who understands the Federal Reserve very well and shares its values.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And as I mentioned in my opening statement, he is committed to the mission of the Fed; to its independence; and to its acting in a nonpartisan, nonpolitical way.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: He is somebody who has participated in the FOMC now for many years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: To the best of my knowledge, he has been part of the consensus.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I don’t believe he’s ever dissented.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I think there is strong consensus in the Committee for the gradual approach that we have been pursuing, and Governor Powell has been part of that consensus, so I feel he’s very well positioned and very knowledgeable of all the ins and outs of everything that the Fed does.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: In supervision, in the payment system—he’s played an active role there—and in monetary policy, and I have confidence that he is very capable of steering the Federal Reserve in the years ahead.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Do you mean me, or—as long as everyone gets a turn.
Speaker: JOHN HELTMAN.

Sentence: This is John Heltman with the American Banker.
Speaker: JOHN HELTMAN.

Sentence: Sort of a related question to what Nancy was asking—there have been some reservations among some Democratic senators recently during Governor Powell’s confirmation hearing and during the markup of the reg relief bill about the approach towards regulation that the new leadership appears to be adopting.
Speaker: JOHN HELTMAN.

Sentence: Do you have any similar reservations about the new leadership’s ability to deregulate in an evenhanded way that keeps an eye towards the stability of the financial system and the—sort of, the advances that have come from post-crisis regulation?
Speaker: JOHN HELTMAN.

Sentence: So I would say that all of my colleagues on the Board have expressed a strong commitment to keep in place the core reforms that have produced a stronger financial system.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I’m considering there stronger capital, particularly for the most systemic institutions—higher-quality capital, stronger liquidity requirements, a rigorous stress-testing program, and resolution planning that will make it more possible to resolve a firm that encounters significant distress.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I have heard broad-based commitment to those things, and I think they are the core of the reforms we have put in place.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I think all of us agree that it is appropriate to tailor regulatory requirements in all of those areas and others to the systemic footprint of firms.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We have done a lot to do that, and I think there is more that could be done, and in some areas it would require legislation in order to do that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But I believe all of my colleagues and I are in agreement on that, and we’re also focused on community banks and want to find ways to relieve burdens.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So in those important ways, I do think that all of my colleagues are in the same place with respect to their priorities.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Are there any important differences between your colleagues and your vision on regulatory reform?
Speaker: JOHN HELTMAN.

Sentence: So I have not seen anything emerge at this point that I would describe as a significant difference.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Hi, Howard Schneider with Reuters.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentence: So you mentioned in response to Steve’s question that asset valuations, you didn’t think, were on the sort of high-priority risk list right now.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentence: So I’m wondering, what do you think is on that risk list?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentence: And, more broadly, what have you left undone?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentence: You’ve gotten high marks for bringing the economy back towards its goals, but are there things that are going to nag you when you walk out of here in February and say, “Really, I wish I’d seen this to completion”?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentence: I mean, we’re not doing negative interest rates.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentence: We’re not doing inflation framework.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentence: What’s at your top of—what’s at the top of the to-do list that you are not getting to see to bring to ground here?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentence: So you asked about the risk list.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: There are always risks that affect the outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We tend to focus in our own evaluation on economic risks, and we’ve characterized them as “balanced.”  And I think they are balanced.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: You know, I can always give you a list of, you know, potential troubles, international developments that could result in downside economic risk.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But, look, at the moment the U.S. economy is performing well.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The growth that we’re seeing, it’s not based on, for example, an unsustainable buildup of debt as we had in the run-up to the financial crisis.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The global economy is doing well.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We’re in a synchronized expansion.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: This is the first time in many years that we’ve seen this.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Inflation around the world is generally low.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I think the risks are balanced, and there’s less to lose sleep about now than has been true for quite some time, so I feel good about the economic out—the economic outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I feel, you know, good that the labor market is in a very much stronger place than it was eight years ago.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We have created 17 million jobs.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We’ve got a good, strong labor market and a very low unemployment rate, and I think that’s been tremendously important to the well-being of American households and workers.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I feel very pleased when I hear anecdotes from firms that tell me they’re having a hard time finding workers, and they talk about, given that they’re taking on people with skills that don’t quite match what they want, but they’re training them, and, you know, giving them the training that they need in order to be able to fill jobs.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I think that’s a development that is a natural one that occurs in a strong labor market that tends to build human capital and worker skills, and that that’s a strong positive.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As I mentioned, I think the financial system is on much sounder footing, and that we have done a great deal to put in place greater capital, liquidity, and so forth that make it less crisis prone, and that has been an important objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: What’s on my “undone” list, you ask?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We have a 2 percent symmetric inflation objective, and, for a number of years now, inflation has been running under 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I consider it an important priority to make sure that inflation doesn’t chronically undershoot our 2 percent objective, and I want to see it move up to 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So most of my colleagues and I do believe that it’s being held down by transitory factors, but there’s work undone there, in the sense—we need to see it move up in line with our objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Thank you.
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentence: Chair Yellen, what do you think will be the drivers of inflation over the next couple of years, and how long will the Committee go with low unemployment, low inflation before you rethink monetary policy—this gradual rate hikes?
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentence: Thank you.
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentence: So, you know, I think for a number of years—so we’ve had an undershoot of inflation for a number of years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We absolutely recognize that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I think until this year, undershoot was understandable.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: First we had a good deal of slack in the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Then we had plummeting oil prices.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, beginning in mid-2014, there was a marked depreciation in the dollar.2  And those three factors held down inflation for a number of years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Now, in 2016, core inflation came very close to 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We seemed to be on a path of inflation moving up, and this year, beginning in March, there seemed to be a sequence of negative surprises.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Some reflect one-time factors that were easily identifiable, like a marked decline in quality-adjusted cell phone plans.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: There may be other factors that are not so easy to name, but we would judge—you know, inflation doesn’t always follow exactly.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: There are errors and many factors that affect it beyond the key influences of labor market slack:  exchange rates and import prices and oil prices.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Those are three big ones.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But there are other factors that affect inflation too, and our judgment at this point is that transitory factors that are unrelated to the broader macroeconomic outlook are holding inflation down.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But I have tried to be straightforward in saying that this could end up being something that is more ingrained and turns out to be permanent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It’s very important to watch it and, if necessary, rethink what’s determining inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: A possibility is that the longer-run sustainable                                                  rate of unemployment is—it’s been coming down.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Estimates in the Committee have come down.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It’s conceivable that they need to come down even more.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It’s not my judgment that inflation expectations have slipped, but that also remains a possibility that needs to be monitored.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So there are—you know, there could be a rethink of inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I think it’s important to watch inflation outcomes carefully and, if we don’t see inflation moving in the manner that the Committee anticipates, to alter policy so that we do achieve our 2 percent objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But, at the moment, most of my colleagues and I believe we are on track to achieve it.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Hi, Chair Yellen.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: Jim Puzzanghera with the Los Angeles Times.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: I’m wondering, you mentioned this is your last news conference.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: What are your plans when you step down from the Fed?
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: Are you going to remain in Washington?
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: Will you go back to Berkeley?
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: And, also, I’m curious if you have any disappointment that you’re not going to be continuing in this job as some of your predecessors have done.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: So, on my plans, I don’t have anything definite for you, I guess.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I have a home in Berkeley and expect to maintain it.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But I would say, my spouse is on the faculty—he’s a professor at Georgetown and would like to stay in his job, and we expect to maintain Washington as our base.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But I don’t have any definite plans.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Let’s see.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And you asked me if I’m disappointed.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So let me just say that I have served in senior positions in the Federal Reserve now for quite a long time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I became president in San Francisco in 2004, and I’ve participated in the FOMC since that time as president, as Vice Chair, and as Chair, and it’s been an immensely rewarding experience for me.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I feel very positive about what we’ve been able to accomplish and feel tremendous, you know, loyalty to the institution.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I did make the judgment that this is the right time for me to leave, but I feel I have served in senior positions at the Fed for a long time, and it’s really been an honor and a privilege for me to have had a chance to do so.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Adam Shapiro with Fox Business.
Speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO.

Sentence: Glad to hear you’re staying on the East Coast.
Speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO.

Sentence: I’m just curious, I wanted to follow up to the bitcoin questions, but—because you’ve lived through what we all experienced in 2007, 2008, and—should the Fed take a more active role in trying to identify who some of the counterparty and what the exposure is with bitcoin as a potential threat to financial stability?
Speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO.

Sentence: Just—the best minds at the Fed can sometimes miss these kinds of threats.
Speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO.

Sentence: Your predecessor, Mr. Bernanke, actually said in ’07 that the contagion from subprime would not affect the housing market or the economy.
Speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO.

Sentence: So are we underestimating the potential threat from bitcoin as it runs up in value?
Speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO.

Sentence: Well, I certainly agree that it’s important for the Fed to attempt to understand emerging risks to financial stability and to be looking not just in the banking system but outside it for developments that could pose financial risks, and we are doing that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, I would say, one of the changes during my tenure is, we devoted—decided in the aftermath of the crisis that we needed to devote considerable resources to financial stability to monitor for emerging threats, and now we have at the Board a full-blown division of financial stability that’s involved in doing that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Now, when you ask about bitcoin, I still see the financial stability risks from it as limited.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Often, risks threatening financial stability arise when there’s exposure of the banking system to fluctuating asset valuations, and I really don’t see any significant exposure of our core financial institutions to threats from bitcoin if its value were to fluctuate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I don’t see a threat to our core financial institutions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So, undoubtedly, there are individuals who could lose a lot of money if bitcoin were to fall in price, but I really don’t see that as creating a full-blown financial stability risk.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Michael McKee from Bloomberg Television and Radio.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: I suppose I should be asking you a valedictory question since it’s the last question, but I don’t think you can top what you’ve already said, so let me just do a couple of cleanup questions here.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: President Trump, while you were speaking, just said that he thinks his tax plan will produce 4 percent growth.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: Do you think that is possible?
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: Second, do you think that there is any Fed blame or complicity in the flattening of the yield curve, and are you worried that there might be some sort of policy mistake built into that that could slow the economy?
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And the last question, which is a bit of a valedictory, is one that everybody on Wall Street has wanted to ask you for four years.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: Since this is your last press conference, can you tell us which dot is yours?
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: [Laughter] CHAIR YELLEN.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: Well, I can answer the last question first.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: The answer is “no.”  I’ve never been willing to reveal which dot is mine, and I’m not going to change that now.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: So, you know, my assessment, and I think most participants’ assessments, as I said, of the impact of the tax policy on growth has been informed by work by the Joint Committee on Taxation and other analysts.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And everyone recognizes that there’s uncertainty about what the economic effects would be, and I wouldn’t want to rule anything out.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: It is challenging, however, to achieve growth of the levels that you mentioned.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: Look, if the package were to stimulate growth of that magnitude, let me just say again, the Federal Reserve would welcome that.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: If it’s a supply-side—favorable supply-side developments that would be compatible with the attainment of our employment and inflation objectives, that’s something that would be very, very welcome.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: But it would be challenging to achieve numbers like that.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: Let’s see, I think you also then asked me about the yield curve, and—I mean, there is much discussion about yield curve inversions and whether or not a flattening yield curve could signal a recession.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: Is that the brunt of your question?
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And whether the Fed has made—if there’s a policy mistake embedded in that.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: So this is something that we discussed and have looked at.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The yield curve has flattened some as we have raised short rates.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It mainly—the flattening yield curve mainly reflects higher short-term rates.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The yield curve is not currently inverted, and I would say that the current slope is well within its historical range.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Now, there is a strong correlation historically between yield curve inversions and recessions, but let me emphasize that correlation is not causation, and I think that there are good reasons to think that the relationship between the slope of the yield curve and the business cycle may have changed.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And one reason for that is that long-term interest rates generally embody two factors.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: One is the expected average value of short rates over, say, 10 years, and the second piece of it is a so-called term premium that often reflects things like inflation—inflation risk.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Typically, the term premium historically has been positive.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So when the yield curve has inverted historically, it meant that short-term rates were well above average expected short rates over the longer run.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So with the positive term premium, that’s what it means.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And typically that means that monetary policy is restrictive, sometimes quite restrictive, and some of those recessions were situations in which the Fed was consciously tightening monetary policy because inflation was high and trying to slow the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Well, right now the term premium is estimated to be quite low, close to zero, and that means that, structurally—and this can be true going forward—that the yield curve is likely to be flatter than it’s been in the past.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And so it could more easily invert.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: If the Fed were to even move to a slightly restrictive policy stance, you could see an inversion with a zero term premium.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I think the fact the term premium is so low and the yield curve is generally flatter is an important factor to consider.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Now, I think it’s also important to realize that market participants are not expressing heightened concern about the decline of the term premium, and, when asked directly about the odds of recession, they see it as low, and I would concur with that judgment.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Thanks very much.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.
